unnormalised: **What's the vibe like in the Urban Gym Culture these days? Is it all just protein shakes and flexing?**
normalised: **What is the vibe like in the Urban Gym Culture these days? Is it all just protein shakes and flexing?**

unnormalised: Honestly, it's a bit of both, right? In cities like Mumbai and Bangalore, you see a real shift. It's no longer just about losing weight for your cousin's wedding. There's a growing understanding of fitness as a lifestyle.
normalised: Honestly, it is a bit of both, right? In cities like Mumbai and Bangalore, you see a real shift. It is no longer just about losing weight for your cousin's wedding. There is a growing understanding of fitness as a lifestyle.

unnormalised: You've got your hardcore lifters aiming for Mr. India, chugging creatine like it's chai at a tapri. And then you have the folks more interested in group classes – Zumba, HIIT, yoga – for that endorphin rush. Instagram definitely plays a part. Everyone wants that perfect post-workout selfie, showing off their gains (or the illusion of them!).
normalised: You have got your hardcore lifters aiming for Mister India, chugging creatine like it is chai at a tapri. And then you have the folks more interested in group classes – Zumba, H I I T, yoga – for that endorphin rush. Instagram definitely plays a part. Everyone wants that perfect post-workout selfie, showing off their gains (or the illusion of them!).

unnormalised: But I think there's also a genuine community aspect. People motivating each other, sharing workout tips. You even see friends who met at the gym going for weekend treks to places like Lonavala.
normalised: But I think there is also a genuine community aspect. People motivating each other, sharing workout tips. You even see friends who met at the gym going for weekend treks to places like Lonavala.

unnormalised: Of course, there are the downsides. Pressure to look a certain way can be intense. And some gyms in posher areas charge exorbitant fees – almost as much as tuition at IIT! The focus can sometimes be too much on aesthetics and not enough on actual well-being. Remember the scene in "Dil Dhadakne Do" where everyone's obsessed with their diet and workout? Sometimes it feels like that!

unnormalised: Ultimately, it's a mixed bag. But if you find a gym with good vibes and focus on feeling good, not just looking good, you're golden. I personally prefer the smaller, less flashy gyms; much more down-to-earth. What are your experiences? Let me know in the comments!
